revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2601:46:200:27F7:5119:8EEC:568B:CFA6|2601:46:200:27F7:5119:8EEC:568B:CFA6]] ([[User talk:2601:46:200:27F7:5119:8EEC:568B:CFA6|talk]]): Block evasion by [[User:BushidoBrown]]. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox person |name = Patina Miller |image = Patina Miller.jpg |birth_name = Patina Renea Miller |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1984|11|6}} |birth_place = Pageland, South Carolina, U.S. |caption = Patina Miller attends 13th Annual Broadway Barks Benefit on July 9, 2011 at Shubert Alley in New York City. |origin = [[Pageland, South Carolina]], U.S. |occupation = Singer, actress |years_active = 2007–present |alma_mater = [[Carnegie Mellon University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Fine Arts|BFA]])}} |spouse = {{marriage|David Mars|2014}} |children = 1 }} '''Patina Renea Miller''' (born November 6, 1984) is an American actress and singer. Miller is best known for originating the role of [[disco]] [[diva]] wannabe Deloris Van Cartier in the 2009 [[West End theatre|West End]] and 2011 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions of ''[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]]''. She also starred as the Leading Player in the 2013 revival of ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]''. This role earned her a [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical]].
She is also known for her role as [[List of The Hunger Games characters#Commander Paylor|Commander Paylor]] in ''[[The Hunger Games (film series)|The Hunger Games: Mockingjay]]'' films, and her starring role as Daisy Grant in the [[CBS]] political drama ''[[Madam Secretary (TV series)|Madam Secretary]]''.
==Early life and education== Born in [[Pageland, South Carolina]],<ref name=Website>{{cite web |url=http://www.sisteractthemusical.com/cast/patina-miller.php |title=Patina Miller, Deloris Van Cartier |last= |first= |date= |website=[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]] |publisher= |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603000609/http://www.sisteractthemusical.com/cast/patina-miller.php |archive-date=June 3, 2009}}</ref> and raised in a single parent home,<ref name=Whats>{{cite web |url=https://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/news/brief-encounter-with-patina-miller_16921.html |title=Brief Encounter With … Patina Miller |last=Bosanquet |first=Theo |date=June 1, 2009 |website=[[WhatsOnStage.com]] |publisher= |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote=}}</ref> she was introduced to music at an early age and sang with the [[gospel choir]] at her local church. She attended [[South Carolina Governor's School for the Arts & Humanities]]<ref name=Blog>{{cite web |url=http://pagelandblog.blogspot.com/2007/05/rising-star.html |title=Rising Star |last=McBride |first=Wallace |date=May 2, 2007 |website=The Pageland Blog |publisher= |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080604101327/http://pagelandblog.blogspot.com/2007/05/rising-star.html |archive-date=June 4, 2008}}</ref> and in 2006 graduated with a degree in [[musical theatre]] from [[Carnegie Mellon University]], which she attended on a full scholarship.<ref name=Website /> She has credited her time at Carnegie Mellon as a big part of her life, saying, "It was there that I studied and really realized that I could make my dream a reality. I'm so thankful to all my teachers who helped me to become the performer I am today. I'm so proud of my school and feel so blessed to have gotten such a wonderful education and made lifelong friends."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cmu.edu/homepage/creativity/2009/spring/sister-act.shtml |title=Patina Miller Lands Idol's Role |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=[[Carnegie Mellon University]] |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote=}}</ref>
==Career== In 2005, Miller was one of three finalists for the role of Effie White in the musical drama ''[[Dreamgirls (film)|Dreamgirls]]'', which ultimately won [[Jennifer Hudson]] the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]].<ref name=Blog /> In 2007, she was cast as Pam Henderson in the daytime [[soap opera]] ''[[All My Children]]'' and appeared in 30 episodes of the show.<ref name=Blog /> She performed in a [[Central Park]] production of ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' in the summer of 2008 and was featured in the musical ''Romantic Poetry'' at the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]] that fall.<ref name=Broadway>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadway.com/buzz/98096/patina-miller-wins-starring-role-in-west-end-musical-version-of-sister-act/ |title=Patina Miller Wins Starring Role in West End Musical Version of Sister Act |last= |first= |date=January 29, 2009 |website=Broadway.com |publisher= |access-date=March 11, 2019 |quote=}}</ref>
[[File:Patina Miller West End Live 2010.jpg|thumb|Miller during a performance of Sister Act on the West End, 2010|alt=|left]]
Miller was cast as the lead role of Delores Van Cartier in ''Sister Act'', a role she had understudied for six months during its initial run in the United States,<ref name="Whats" /> following a year-long international search.<ref name="Broadway" /> The London production opened on June 2, 2009 at the [[London Palladium]], and although it received mixed reviews, most critics singled out Miller and praised her performance. [[Benedict Nightingale]] of ''[[The Times]]'' cited her "terrific voice" and continued, "Add warmth, humour, vivacity—and you've a star who lacks [[Whoopi Goldberg|Whoopi's]] wry vulnerability but adds dazzle to the razzle around her,"<ref>{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/theatre/article6417198.ece |title=Sister Act at the London Palladium |last=Nightingale |first=Benedict |date=June 3, 2009 |work=[[The Sunday Times]] |publisher= |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617011311/http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/stage/theatre/article6417198.ece |archive-date=June 17, 2011}}</ref> while David Benedict of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' thought her "powerhouse vocals, pitched somewhere between [[Gloria Gaynor]] and [[Whitney Houston]], and her thrillingly fast [[vibrato]] act as the show's engine."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2009/legit/reviews/sister-act-4-1200507080/ |title=Sister Act |last=Benedict |first=David |date=June 3, 2009 |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |publisher= |access-date=June 4, 2009 |quote=}}</ref> For this role Miller won the whatsonstage.com Theatregoers Choice Award for Best Actress in a Musical and was also nominated for the [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.whatsonstage.com/west-end-theatre/news/full-list-2010-whatsonstagecom-award-winners_14392.html |title=Full List: 2010 Whatsonstage.com Award Winners |last= |first= |date=February 14, 2010 |website=[[WhatsOnStage.com]] |publisher= |access-date=May 24, 2010 |quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/spring-awakening-enron-and-red-score-big-in-olivier-nominations-com-165586 |title=''Spring Awakening'', ''Enron'' and ''Red Score'' Big in Olivier Nominations |last=Shenton |first=Mark |date=February 8, 2010 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=May 24, 2010 |quote=}}</ref> She remained with the production till it closed on October 30, 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.westendtheatre.com/7569/news/avenue-q-sister-act-close-tonight/ |title=Avenue Q, Sister Act Close Tonight |last= |first= |date=October 30, 2010 |work=West End Theatre |publisher= |access-date=March 7, 2012 |quote=}}</ref>
Miller reprised the role of Deloris Van Cartier in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of ''Sister Act'', which began performances on March 24, 2011, at the [[The Broadway Theatre|Broadway Theatre]] and officially opened April 20, 2011. Miller also made her Broadway debut in this production.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/patina-miller-to-star-in-broadways-sister-act-the-musical-com-173221 |title=Patina Miller to Star in Broadway's ''Sister Act The Musical'' |last=Hetrick |first=Adam |date=November 1, 2010 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=November 2, 2010 |quote=}}</ref> For this role she won a [[Theatre World Award]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/ellen-barkin-patina-miller-john-larroquette-jim-parsons-tony-sheldon-and-more-win-theatre-world-awards-com-179031 |title=Ellen Barkin, Patina Miller, John Larroquette, Jim Parsons, Tony Sheldon and More Win Theatre World Awards |last=Gans |first=Andrew |date=May 10, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=May 10, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> and was also nominated for the [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/2011-tony-nominations-announced-book-of-mormon-earns-14-nominations-com-178833 |title=2011 Tony Nominations Announced; ''Book of Mormon'' Earns 14 Nominations |last1=Jones |first1=Kenneth |last2=Gans |first2=Andrew |date=May 3, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=May 3, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> the [[Outer Critics Circle Award|Outer Critics Circle Award for Outstanding Actress in a Musical]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/outer-critics-circle-nominees-include-sister-act-anything-goes-book-of-mormon-com-178581 |title=Outer Critics Circle Nominees Include ''Sister Act, Anything Goes, Book of Mormon'' |last=Gans |first=Andrew |date=April 26, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=April 30, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> the [[Drama League Award|Drama League Award for Distinguished Performance]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/book-of-mormon-priscilla-sister-act-war-horse-good-people-and-more-are-drama-league-nominees-com-178535 |title=''Book of Mormon, Priscilla, Sister Act, War Horse, Good People'' and More Are Drama League Nominees |last=Gans |first=Andrew |date=April 25, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=April 30, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> and the [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Musical]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/56th-annual-drama-desk-nominations-announced-book-of-mormon-scores-12-nominations-com-178693 |title=56th Annual Drama Desk Nominations Announced; ''Book of Mormon'' Scores 12 Nominations |last=Gans |first=Andrew |date=April 29, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=April 30, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> She played her final performance in the Broadway company on March 18, 2012 and was replaced by [[Raven-Symoné]] on March 27.<ref name="Raven">{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Its-Official-Shes-Fabulous-Raven-Symone-Joins-SISTER-ACT-Mar-27-Patina-Miller-Departs-Mar-18-20120307 |title=It's Official: She's Fabulous! Raven-Symone Joins SISTER ACT Mar. 27; Patina Miller Departs Mar. 18 |last= |first= |date=March 7, 2012 |work=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=March 7, 2012 |quote=}}</ref> Miller also starred as Linda in the [[New York City Center|City Center]] [[Encores!]] production of ''[[Lost in the Stars]]'', which ran from February 3–6, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/encores-lost-in-the-stars-to-feature-chuck-cooper-daniel-breaker-patina-miller-com-175068 |title=Encores! ''Lost in the Stars'' to Feature Chuck Cooper, Daniel Breaker, Patina Miller |last=Gans |first=Andrew |date=January 10, 2011 |work=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=January 10, 2011 |quote=}}</ref>
She performed as the Leading Player in the [[American Repertory Theater]] production of ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'' from December 5, 2012 to January 20, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Patina-Miller-Matthew-James-Thomas-and-More-to-Lead-PIPPIN-at-ART-Full-Cast-Announced-20121010 |title=Patina Miller, Matthew James Thomas and More to Lead PIPPIN at A.R.T. - Full Cast Announced! |last= |first= |date=October 10, 2012 |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=November 15, 2012 |quote=}}</ref> Miller recently reprised the role in the Broadway revival, which began performances on March 23, 2013, at the [[Music Box Theatre]] and officially opened on April 25, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://playbill.com/news/article/174665-Pippin-Will-Arrive-on-Broadway-With-Complete-ART-Cast-Including-Patina-Miller-Matthew-James-Thomas-Andrea-Martin- |title=''Pippin'' Will Arrive on Broadway With Complete A.R.T. Cast, Including Patina Miller, Matthew James Thomas, Andrea Martin |last=Hetrick |first=Adam |date=February 4, 2013 |website=[[Playbill]] |publisher= |access-date=February 4, 2013 |quote= |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216155551/http://playbill.com/news/article/174665-Pippin-Will-Arrive-on-Broadway-With-Complete-ART-Cast-Including-Patina-Miller-Matthew-James-Thomas-Andrea-Martin- |archive-date=February 16, 2013}}</ref> She won the Outer Critics Circle Award and [[Tony Award for Best Actress in a Musical]] at the [[67th Tony Awards]] for this role.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/pippin-is-big-winner-of-2012-13-outer-critics-circle-awards-com-204640|title=''Pippin'' Is Big Winner of 2012-13 Outer Critics Circle Awards|accessdate=May 13, 2013|date=May 13, 2013|work=[[Playbill]]|last=Gans|first=Andrew}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/kinky-boots-vanya-and-sonia-pippin-and-virginia-woolf-are-big-winners-at-67th-annual-tony-awards-com-206467 |title=Kinky Boots, Vanya and Sonia, Pippin and Virginia Woolf? Are Big Winners at 67th Annual Tony Awards |accessdate=June 10, 2013 |date=June 9, 2013 |work=[[Playbill]] |last=Purcell |first=Carey}}</ref>
Miller played Commander Paylor in ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]'' (2014) and ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2|Part 2]]'' in 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/09/18/hunger-games-patina-miller-commander-paylor/2832751/ |title='Hunger Games' casts Broadway's Patina Miller |last=Mallenbaum |first=Carly |date=September 18, 2013 |work=[[USA Today]] |publisher= |access-date=November 27, 2013 |quote=}}</ref> In May 2014, it was announced that she was cast as Daisy Grant, press coordinator to Secretary of State [[Elizabeth McCord (character)|Elizabeth McCord]] ([[Téa Leoni]]) in the CBS political drama ''[[Madam Secretary (TV series)|Madam Secretary]]''. The show premiered on Sunday, September 21, 2014, on [[CBS]] as part of the [[2014-15 United States network television schedule|2014–15 television season]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/smashs-katharine-mcphee-star-cbs-689175 |title='Smash's' Katharine McPhee to Star in CBS Genius Drama (Exclusive) |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=March 17, 2014 |accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2014/05/09/cbs-orders-ncis-new-orleans-the-odd-couple-stalker-madam-secretary-scorpion-the-mccarthys/262481/ |title=CBS Orders 'CSI: Cyber', 'NCIS: New Orleans', 'The Odd Couple', 'Stalker', 'Madam Secretary', 'Scorpion' & 'The McCarthys' |last=Kondolojy |first=Amanda |website=[[TV by the Numbers]] |date=May 9, 2014 |accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvline.com/2014/05/09/cbs-fall-2014-new-series-ncis-new-orleans-odd-couple/ |title=Fall TV: CBS Orders NCIS and CSI Spin-Offs, Odd Couple, Kevin Williamson's Stalker and 4 More to Series (But Not How I Met Your Dad?) |last=Swift |first=Andy |website=[[TVLine]] |date=May 9, 2014 |accessdate=May 10, 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== On June 14, 2014, Miller married venture capitalist David Mars in New York City. Robin Burch, Miller’s mother, who is a Baptist minister, officiated at the ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/07/13/fashion/weddings/on-stage-and-in-his-life-the-leading-player.html?_r=0#|title=On Stage and in His Life, the Leading Player|first=Dave|last=Itzkoff| date=11 July 2014|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|location=New York City}}</ref> Their daughter, Emerson Harper, was born on August 9, 2017 in New York City. <ref>{{cite web |url=https://people.com/parents/patina-miller-welcomes-daughter-emerson-harper/ |title=Patina Miller Welcomes Daughter Emerson Harper |last=Juneau |first=Jen |date=August 11, 2017 |work=[[People (magazine)|People]] |publisher= |access-date=September 4, 2017 |quote=}}</ref>
==Discography== * ''Sister Act (Original London Cast Recording)'' (2009)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/uk-regional/article/SISTER-ACT-The-Musical-To-Release-Cast-Recording-727-20090727 |title=SISTER ACT: The Musical To Release Cast Recording 7/27 |last= |first= |date=July 27, 2009 |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=January 10, 2011 |quote=}}</ref> * ''What I Wanna Be When I Grow Up'' by Scott Alan, singing the song "Taking Back My Life" (2010)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Photo-Coverage-The-Songs-of-Scott-Alan-at-Barnes-Noble-20101204 |title=Photo Coverage: The Songs of Scott Alan at Barnes & Noble |last=Rafter Keddy |first=Genevieve |date=December 4, 2010 |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=December 7, 2010 |quote=}}</ref> * ''Out of Our Heads'' by [[Kooman and Dimond]], singing the song "Random Black Girl" (2011)<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Patina-Miller-Leads-Kooman-Dimond-Concert-at-Birdland-718-20110628 |title=Patina Miller Leads Kooman & Dimond Concert at Birdland, 7/18 |last= |first= |date=June 28, 2011 |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=April 26, 2013 |quote=}}</ref> * ''Pippin (New Broadway Cast Recording)'' (2013)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://broadwayworld.com/article/PIPPIN-Cast-Recording-Track-Listing-Announced-Bonus-Tracks-Included-20130603 |title=PIPPIN Cast Recording Released Today! |last= |first= |date=June 4, 2013 |website=[[BroadwayWorld]] |publisher= |access-date=June 15, 2013 |quote=}}</ref>
==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 2014 | ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]'' | Commander Paylor | |- | 2015 | ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 2]]'' | Commander Paylor | |- |}
===Television=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 2007–08 | ''[[All My Children]]'' | Pam Henderson | 30 episodes |- | 2012 | ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]'' | Deloris Van Cartier | Episode: "#4.35" |- | 2014–19 | ''[[Madam Secretary (TV series)|Madam Secretary]]'' | Daisy Grant | 108 episodes |- | 2016–present | ''[[Word Party]]'' | Narrator | 45 episodes |- | 2017 | ''[[Mercy Street (TV series)|Mercy Street]]'' | Charlotte | 6 episodes |- | 2021 | ''Power Book III: Raising Kanan'' | Raquel Thomas | Upcoming |- |}
===Theatre=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | 2006 | rowspan="2"|''[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]]'' | rowspan="2"|Ensemble/Deloris Van Cartier (understudy) | [[Pasadena Playhouse]] |- | 2007 | [[Alliance Theatre Company]] |- | 2008 | ''[[Hair (musical)|Hair]]'' | Sheila | Central Park |- | 2009 | ''[[Putting It Together]]'' | Performer | New York |- | 2010 | rowspan="2"|''[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]]'' | rowspan="2"|Deloris Van Cartier | West End |- | 2011–12 | Broadway |- | 2012 | ''[[Lost in the Stars]]'' | Linda | [[Encores!]] |- | 2013–14 | ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'' | Leading Player | Broadway |- | 2019 | ''[[Into The Woods]]'' | The Witch | [[Hollywood Bowl]] |}
===Concerts=== In 2014, she performed at [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]]. The concert was broadcast on PBS as ''Patina Miller in Concert''.
==Awards and nominations== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Award ! Category ! Nominated work ! Result |- | 2010 | [[Laurence Olivier Award]] | [[Laurence Olivier Award for Best Actress in a Musical|Best Actress in a Musical]] | rowspan="6"| ''[[Sister Act (musical)|Sister Act]]'' | {{nom}} |- | rowspan="5"| 2011 | [[Tony Award]] | [[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical|Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama Desk Award]] | [[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actress in a Musical|Outstanding Actress in a Musical]] | {{nom}} |- | [[Drama League Award]] | Distinguished Performance | {{nom}} |- | [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] | Outstanding Actress in a Musical | {{nom}} |- | colspan="2"| [[Theatre World Award]] | {{won}} |- | rowspan="4"| 2013 | [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] | Outstanding Actress in a Musical | rowspan="4"| ''[[Pippin (musical)|Pippin]]'' | {{won}} |- | [[Drama League Award]] | Distinguished Performance | {{nom}} |- | [[Tony Award]] | Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical | {{won}} |- | Fred and Adele Astaire Awards | Outstanding Female Dancer in a Broadway Show | {{Nominated}} |- | 2015 | [[Black Reel Award]] | Outstanding Female Breakthrough Performance | ''[[The Hunger Games: Mockingjay – Part 1]]'' | {{nom}} |}
